reviews.title: Clear explanation in lectures. I think book is a must.
reviews.comment_content:
The course clearly divided the analyses of Macroeconomics into parts: Short-Run Model (ISLM), Medium-Run Model (ASAD, which incorporates price level) and Long-Run Growth model, which copes mainly with capital and technology.

However, in the last few lectures (2-3, as I remember), a little introduction to open economy (incorporating export and import) was made.

Overall, I think the content included in the course is quite a lot, compared to Microeconomics(ECON 2103). And the difficulty of Macroeconomics should be a little bit higher than Microeconomics. As 2103 is mostly common sense. 2123 is getting tough starting from medium-run model. And since Short-run model (ISLM) is used for BOTH medium-run and open economy and it was also the only topic tested in midterm, make sure you understand the content before midterm well.

reviews.comment_content:
Its quite interesting actually, it is quite relevant to our life. u get to study about how the economy work as a whole. Like how interest rate affect output (GDP), how government policies affect the economy and the relationship between output and price level with the aid of model. (needless to say: way more complicated than micro, much more factors to consider)

Course outline
Part 1: Introduction to macroeconomics  CH. 1-2
- Introduce the concept of GDP, inflation, unemployment

Part 2: The short run closed economy (IS-LM model) CH. 3-5
- talk about the goods and financial market, combining both market together to construct the IS-LM model. Apply the IS-LM model to predict and explain effects of fiscal and monetary policy, both separately and together.

**basically these first 2 parts takes up almost half of the course, make sure you fully understand these 2 part as these concept are very important for the remaining part

Part 3:   The short run open economy (IS-LM-UIP model)
- considering trade, export and import to talk about part 2 again, while introducing new concepts like real depreciation, interest parity condition, flexible/fixed exchange rate

Part 4: The medium run (AS-AD Model) CH. 6-7
- Discuss about the labor market, then the AS-AD model, and then AS-AD together with the IS-LM model

Part 5: The long run (Solow model) CH 10-12.1
- interactions between output and capital. effects of saving rate on capital, output, and consumption. balanced growth...etc

for me part 3 and 5 are the hardest, but many found part 4 the hardest. (maybe I dont have DSE econ so it confuse me less when new concepts that deviated from the dse syllabus are introduced)

reviews.author: hw1
reviews.title: Decent Course, Horrible Professor
reviews.comment_content:
The general content of this course is fine, it teaches about the AS-AD model, different markets (money market, labor market, goods market), economic fluctuations and causes (recession, depression, technological shocks etc.), exchange rate, and economic growth. You can expect to have the 'theoretical knowledge' of how the macro-economy works, but indeed it is very theoretical, and you could learn a lot more and much faster through Investopedia, YouTube etc. which actually gives real-life knowledge to understand the economy.

If you're planning to take this as a Common Core, be sure to look at the in-depth Syllabus before hand to make sure you would like to study these topics in-depth, theoretically (not very interesting, in my opinion). As I said, online resources would be more helpful if you're looking to gain understanding on the economy, i.e. Ray Dalio: How the Economic Machine Works - an in-depth 30min video on YouTube about the general workings of the macro economy.

Syllabus Outline:
=========================
Introduction (Chapters 1-2)
- Economy in the short run

The Goods Market (Chapter 3)
- Financial Markets I (Chapter 4)
- Goods and Financial Markets: The IS-LM model (Chapter 5)

Economy in the medium run
- The Labor Market (Chapter 7)
- Putting All Markets together (Chapter 7 of the 6th edition of the book)

Open Economy
- Openness in Goods and Financial Markets (Chapter 17)
- The Goods Market in an Open Economy (Chapter 18)
- Output, the Interest Rate, and the Exchange Rate (Chapter 19)
- Exchange Rate Regime (Chapter 20*)

Economic Growth*
- Facts of Growth (Chapter 10*)
- Saving, Capital Accumulation, and Output (Chapter 11*)
- Technological Progress and Growth (Chapter 12*)

Studies on macroeconomic aggregates including GDP, unemployment rate, inflation rate, GDP deflator, consumer price index (CPI), etc.

Discussion into the goods and money markets and the resulting IS and LM relations. Then the 2 markets are put together to develop the IS-LM model.

III) Economy in the medium run
Mainly on the WS and PS relations of the labor market, and the labor market is put together with the IS-LM model to form the AS-AD model.

IV) Economy in the long run
Studies on the effect of saving and capital accumulation on the output in the long run using the Solow model.

V) Open economy
Studies on open economic issues. Incorporates net export and the uncovered interest parity relations to develop the Mundell-Fleming model.

The course content slightly differs from the textbook since his lecture slides are his own interpretations of Macro theories. Unless you are struggling to understand certain concepts, I wouldn't advise using textbooks to revise and instead, I would focus more on his slides and handouts.

Introduction to macroeconomic theory and policy analysis. Significantly harder than ECON 2103 (Microeconomics).

The first part of the course explores how GDP, inflation, unemployment, and other macroeconomic aggregates are measured in practice. “Equilibrium” among these variables in different markets will be studied in the short, the medium, and long run. Goods and money markets are identified by IS-LM model in the short run. Then we move to the labor market and put all the markets together to derive the AS-AD model in the medium run. In the long run, we develop analytical models of macroeconomic performance and growth. Such a theoretical framework will allow us to study the impacts of fiscal and monetary policies on the economy. Last part focuses on open macroeconomic issues.

reviews.comment_grading:
I think it’s pretty decent.
There are two grading schemes. Grading depends on the highest between two.
Scheme 1:
Zoom Participation 7%
Problem Sets 4x2% each = 8%
Quizzes 3x10% each = 30%
Mini Project = 10%
Final = 45%
Scheme 2:
Zoom Participation = 7%
Problem Sets = 4x2% each = 8%
Quizzes = Best2x15% each = 30%
Mini Project = 0%
Final = 55%

Basically, you will get a full in participation if you participate in 90% of classes (around 20). If you can’t meet this requirement, your mark will drop to 4% immediately. Prs are not counted in participation marks, so no worry if you accidentally fall asleep in class.
Problem Sets are marked based on efforts. So just try your best to answer all questions with steps will score you a full in PS.
Mini Project is a must must complete item in FeiDing’s class. Once you finish your presentation, a 10% full will be given unless you have a really poor poor performance. But the slots are limited, you will have to register a place in the first week and there’s around 57 places in one section. Be quick and a 10% will be automatically be in your pocket. If you choose to register mini project, I think your grading system will basically be Scheme 1.
Quizzes are in normal difficulty. All mc questions, but time is quite constrained. 25 minutes for 20 questions. So better revise more although it’s an open book quiz. Mean is around 80% (the last one  is around 73) and I got slightly above mean in three quizzes. Only slightly.
Final is much more difficult. It’s cumulative and majority of the questions are from part 4, especially in long questions. Time is very limited again, 100 minutes for a lot of questions. So you really have to be quick. But the mean is relatively low. It’s only 103.75/240, not a half even. Just try your best to revise all lecture materials, and finish problem sets as well as practice paper in your own and you will be fine in the exam.
FYI
Quizzes - 25%/30% (Mean 23.3%)
Final - +1.45 s.d.
Just above 80% and it’s already an A grade. Pretty decent.
Most importantly, I only got a lv2 in DSE Economics, so just revise and practise and it would be fine.
